thread.title: How the Stock Market Reacted To Wells Fargo’s 2Q15 Earnings
thread.title_full: How the Stock Market Reacted To Wells Fargo’s 2Q15 Earnings

title: How the Stock Market Reacted To Wells Fargo’s 2Q15 Earnings
text:
How the Stock Market Reacted To Wells Fargo’s 2Q15 Earnings By Rebecca Keats 28 minutes ago  
( Continued from Prior Part ) Stock performance was subdued compared with JPMorgan 
The stock market’s (SPY) reaction to Wells Fargo’s (WFC) earnings was subdued, as shares of WFC closed at $57.25, rising by a slim 0.93% on July 14. Meanwhile, shares of JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), whose results beat expectations, rallied 1.51% on the same day. Both banks outperformed gains on the Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLF), which added 0.24% on July 14. 
Year-to-date (or YTD) shares of Wells Fargo have added 4.31% in value, while shares of competitors Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) have rallied 2.84% and 8.5% YTD, respectively. Most analysts see upside in WFC 
Shares of Wells Fargo (WFC) are trading slightly above its 20-day moving average of $57. WFC has broken out from its 100-day and 50-day moving average of $56. 
Wall Street analysts expect the stock to rise to target levels of $58.94, while median target estimates for the stock are at $59. The stock still trades below its consensus price target by ~3%. 
WFC is tracked by 39 analysts, most of whom believe the stock has further upside and should be bought at current levels. Out of these, three analysts believe the stock should be sold, while 18 believe investors should remain invested in the stock, rating it as a “hold.” 
At a price-to-book value ratio (or PBV) of 1.74x, WFC is considered overvalued compared with peers like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), and Bank of America (BAC), which trade at a PBV of 1.16x, 0.82x, and 0.77x, respectively, as of July 10. On an average, banks in the XLF ETF trade at a price-to-book value ratio of 1.28x.
